message_1: Suppose $f(z) = z^2-2z+3$ is a complex-valued function on the unit circle $\{z \in \mathbb{C}: |z|=1\}$. Find the complex Fourier coefficients $\hat{f}(n)$ of $f$, where $$\hat{f}(n) = \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}f(e^{i\theta})e^{-in\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta,$$ for all $n\in \mathbb{Z}$.
message_2:
First, we need to rewrite the function $f(z)$ in terms of $e^{i\theta}$ since $|z|=1$. We have $z = e^{i\theta}$, so $z^2 = e^{2i\theta}$ and $z^* = e^{-i\theta}$, where $z^*$ is the complex conjugate of $z$. Now, we can rewrite $f(z)$ as:

$$f(e^{i\theta}) = e^{2i\theta} - 2e^{i\theta} + 3$$

Now, we can compute the Fourier coefficients $\hat{f}(n)$:

$$\hat{f}(n) = \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}(e^{2i\theta} - 2e^{i\theta} + 3)e^{-in\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta$$

Let's split the integral into three parts:

$$\hat{f}(n) = \frac{1}{2\pi}\left(\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}e^{2i\theta}e^{-in\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta - 2\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}e^{i\theta}e^{-in\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta + 3\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}e^{-in\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta\right)$$

Now, we can simplify the integrals:

$$\hat{f}(n) = \frac{1}{2\pi}\left(\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}e^{i(2-n)\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta - 2\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}e^{i(1-n)\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta + 3\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}e^{-in\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta\right)$$

Now, we can evaluate the integrals. Recall that the integral of $e^{ik\theta}$ over $[-\pi, \pi]$ is $2\pi$ if $k=0$ and $0$ otherwise:

$$\hat{f}(n) = \begin{cases}
\frac{1}{2\pi}(0 - 2(2\pi) + 3(2\pi)) & \text{if } n = 0 \\
\frac{1}{2\pi}(0 - 2(0) + 3(0)) & \text{if } n = 1 \\
\frac{1}{2\pi}(2\pi - 2(0) + 3(0)) & \text{if } n = 2 \\
\frac{1}{2\pi}(0 - 2(0) + 3(0)) & \text{if } n \neq 0, 1, 2
\end{cases}$$

Simplifying, we get:

$$\hat{f}(n) = \begin{cases}
\pi & \text{if } n = 0 \\
0 & \text{if } n = 1 \\
1 & \text{if } n = 2 \\
0 & \text{if } n \neq 0, 1, 2
\end{cases}$$
